Problem 1.2 Sliding Around: Translations

The wallpaper on the right has the basic shape of a sailboat. The design is made with repeated transformations of the sailboat shape. Suppose the wallpaper extends in all directions.

Is the transformation a reflection?

Billie claims you could slide the paper in several directions without changing what the eye would see.

Do you agree with Billie?

The basic shape of the sailboat is translated to form an image. The transformation that slides a figure is called a translation. A translation matches each point on the original shape to the corresponding point on the image.

The original butterfly shape has been translated. Each corresponding point on the image slid in the direction of the arrow and the length of the line segment AB.

How does the original shape compare to its image?

In this Problem, we will learn how each point X on the original relates to its image point X’ after a translation. The translation line AB. indicates the length of the slide and the direction. We can use a line segment with an arrow to indicate the length and direction.
